ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is an excellent course that reveals the many interconnected and complex phenomena that come together to form environments of chronic poverty, intergenerational poverty, and poverty traps. It is a well organized and carefully curated class that builds the skills to more critically analyze the issues of poverty slowly and deliberately so that by the end one is able to deeply and critically investigate poverty in a particular political economy environment.
I learned a lot about poverty alleviation methods around the world
What poverty is and the different strategies countries have implemented to fight poverty.
Understanding of different definitions of poverty, different redistributive policies, and political theory on people's preferences for those policies

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall this is a great course! One potential weakness of the course is its general focus on the heteronormative "family." I think the addition of a "queering" of many of the topics would be highly beneficial to the course. This could be as simple as attempting to avoid using gendered heteronormative language when describing families. More rigorously would be the addition of literature which specifically addresses the issues of poverty as they affect people outside of the heteronormative majority.

The course material was interesting but the seminars were often too repetitive. It was hard to have a productive spirited conversation over zoom and it wasn't easy to stay focused when we were doing the same thing for the entire 2 hours. Ana de la O is a wonderful, sweet person and a good professor.
Strength is the presentations and policy memo since its a great way to apply what we learned in class. A weakness is that the class is too quantative.

The class revolves around readings that lay out genuinely interesting & unanswered debates in the field. Professor Ana De La O makes an effort to make the class interesting with different types of assignments and a semester-long group project.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor De La O did an excellent job mediating discussions through the use of the raise hand function as well as offering the option to use two fingers in the camera to respond directly to a point that was just made. This helped discussions to be engaging and organic while still being organized.
I thought the class worked well over Zoom

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Great class that offers important consideration of the state of global poverty politics.

Yeah, I really liked learning about poverty alleviation and the different approaches countries have taken on to address this issue. I will say that this class does focus on econ more, so if you're not interested in this aspect of poverty, then this class might not be for you. However, we also focused on public policy and politics as well.
Yes, however the class is very heavy on research methods.
The class is okay. I don't think you end up getting much out of it that you wouldn't get just from doing the readings
I would recommend the course because it was interesting but it is definitely a lot of reading with other courses.
